												A fun strategy/management game that can keep you occupied for minutes or hours.You are a babysitter to dwarfs. You use arrows, walls and dynamite to guide them towards treasures and away from danger. The dangers that await the dwarfs are lava, water and nasty creatures like goblins and spiders. And the dwarfs love looking for treasure, so much so that they will dig into a lava pit to find some. Fortunately you are given the tools to prevent this from hapening. You get guide arrows to switch their direction, dynamite to create holes for water and lava to flow in and walls to block the flow of water and slow the flow of lava. You can also seal up areas permanently by hardening rock, but this can cost a lot of gold (especially in the harder difficulties).With the game's multiple mode, difficulty and time settings you can enjoy a nice long high score game, or go for a quick 5 minute hardcore challenge. There is also an alternate game, akin to a carnival shooting gallery (throwing axes/shooting at side scrolling targets), which can be fun for a bit.For the achievement & perfect game collectors, this game offers a 2 for 1. Any achievement you get in the paid version will also be unlocked if you play the free version. The achievements themselves are fairly easy to get within a few hours. The only issue is that some of the achievements will not register in the paid version, unless you unlock them in the free version (you can meet the criteria in the paid version and not need to buy the dlc).Overall a nice game, 7/10. Definitely worth picking up in a sale. I wouldn't buy it out of sale (£7.99 / $9.99), but it may be worth it to some, so try the free version first.

												Dwarfs!? Yes you heard correctly. Anyways, the game is a strategic tower defense game where you direct and control dwarves to collect minerals and explore caves.Gameplay:The main goal of the game is to defend your outpost, which is the center of the diggers, and explore as much as possible. Diggers will slowly come out and start digging in random areas. You can let them go loose, or direct them on where to dig. Each time they dig, you earn gold. Gold can be used to make more outposts, hire more warriors, or convert an outpost to have more digger dwarves come out. Warriors and Diggers can be directed to go a certain direction. However, the arrows will stay, which can direct wandering Diggers and Warriors to the same path.Each map has three main things to pay attention to: minerals, caves, and of course your outpost. Minerals are what rake the money in. Caves could contain treasure, but can also be full of danger, which is lava, water, minions, and even boss battles. It is important to defend your outpost from these obstacles, otherwise, it's game over.There are a couple of gamemodes: skirmish, base defense, campaign, and the basic arcade mode. There's a bit of variety in this game, but with a common goal.Controls:Controls are a slight hit-and-miss. The reason being is sometimes the clicks do not register when trying to set up dynamite and outposts. Another problem is that sometimes dwarves will ignore your commands on where to go. Just be sure to pay attention and make sure things are going through.Music:If you're used to medieval tones, then this is the type of music it has. It's a bit upbeat and relaxing...well...contrast to the higher difficulties you end up playing.Graphics:The graphics compare to a typical flash game that caters to a cartoony look. The game is overhead, but the art is still detailed with medieval tones.Story:Not much of a story, lad. But I think yer gonna enjoy the witty dwarf who guides ye through the nooks n crannies. What every dwarf loves is killin monsters, ale, and of course gold...the thing that ties the whole thing togetha. Keep everythin in order, kid, and ye'll have the thickest beard known to every dwarf!Overall:Dwarfs!? is a casual or challenging(depends on how you want it to look or play) tower defense game that could mean hours of fun to earn your medals and get the highest possible score. While the controls are a bit off, the gameplay is still fun and simple. Collect money and explore with many different gamemodes. With a classic medieval tone and dwarves that stay true to their heritage, this game can be enjoyed by people of all ages.Pros:-Relaxing Music-Simple game, but with many possible obstacles.-Variety of difficulties.-Variety of gamemodes.Cons:-Controls are a bit stiff sometimes.

												Ok so the only reason I ever played this game to start with was to get an item in Killing Floor lol. But as it just so happens to be, this isn't a bad little game. It's simple enough in design but can yield a nice challenge. Between the lava rushes and floods, mother nature can be one hateful ♥♥♥♥♥ in this game. You may think having only two environmental hazards would quickly become stale, but I didn't find that to be the case. They can be unforgiving. There are several modes in Dwarfs?! but for the most part your goal is to mine as much of the map as you can, without your base being overcome before the time runs out. In each game you'll have ups and downs contained within caves of unknown content until entrance that could either hold Gold, a Boss, mini-hoard, lava, or water. You can spend in game currency to use blocks that block off cave systems and prevent your workers from breaching the containment area but be warned, if you block off the entire system without first discovering it's contents there will be a penalty in the form of a deduction from your gold... an important item I may add. One tactic you may want to try is blocking off all but 1 square then send in 2 workers with dynamite equipped in case it's lava or water. In that event it's best to sacrifice a worker to make a drainage hole in the earth and completely sealing that hazard, which will give you a bonus. Along the way you may construct outposts with your gold and train warriors and workers. Good thing they put this in because the map is rather large and this will cut down on travel time during combat or intervention. In the harder modes controlling your workers becomes extremely important. There are more hazards to be found and they flow faster so having 2 or 3 workers tap into separate conduits will be a quick death for you. So that's the general idea, I'll let you explore the rest of the game for yourself :)Oh yeah, don't forget about the Killing Floor award, whatever it was. Happy gaming!

												This is repetitive but really fun. It's a casual 2D strategy Indie game which includes a bonus Tower Defense game-mode, and more. This game is more of a game where you run in the background whilst doing other things in the non-virtual world. For example: I love to paint my Games Workshop miniatures, so I play this game in the background, listening to calm, enjoyable music while i'm painting my miniatures. If my Dwarfs need help or require micro-managing so they won't release Doom, I pause my painting and micro-manage them. When it's all safe, I return to painting. The main game-play or game-mode is the, 'Arcade mode'. This is where you select a difficulty a time limit, so a random generated underworld spawns. Your Dwarfs will go mining anywhere they like, although you can set them paths to mine for a bit of gold. Caves will spawn in the map which can contain good or bad things or nothing for your Dwarfs. It could be an empty cave, it could filled with water of lava that will spread killing anything in it's path until contained or until it reaches and destroys your town. It could be filled with goblins, or even a boss goblin; 'Shaman'. It could be filled with treasure or with rich minerals to mine. Minerals will spawn around the map to be mined so it can be turned into gold.The 'Campaign' are basically challenges as well as a tutorial. The 'Skirmish' are basically bonus game-modes. The first one is 'Sandbox'. This is basically where you can play around with the underworld. Spawn in everything you like and mess around with the settings of things like: water or lava speed. You can make the world for your dwarfs to thrive, or just die. It's basically arcade mode but instead of a random generated world, you get to create the world before or during when your dwarfs mine, with no time limit.Rush mode is basically Arcade mode but with one difficulty and no time limit. The catch is however, new Dwarfs spawn all the time and you have 200 lives (so if 200 dwarfs die, you die/loose).Dark mode is like Arcade mode but there is only one difficulty and no time limit. However the catch is, everything that isn't mined is hidden. So you don't know where the minerals are or the caves.Endless mode is basically Arcade mode but you decide how big the map is as well as there is no-time limit.Carnival game mode is basically a bonus game mode. You are a dwarf and you have throw axes at moving targets. You can move within a small area but you only have 10 axes. This game-mode is fun to compete with friends to see who can get the highest score.The last game-mode is called 'Base defence.' This basically tower defence but with a twist. You get to create your own paths with digger Dwarfs. Whenever a portal spawns, just before the goblins spawn, a digger dwarfs spawns. He'll try to dig to your village the quickest way possible, but you can always create him your own paths, for some money. Whenever you kill a goblin, you get money. And like any other tower defence game, you can buy towers and then upgrade them.Overall I think this game is great and fun to play. It's worth getting this game if you like casual games.

												[Note: If you're considering this game, I would recommend trying the free-to-play version, which is listed as "Dwarfs - F2P" on Steam. Posted: March 12, 2014
												A fun, cute, casual game.  At its core this game is like a very basic version of pacman meets minecraft.  Dwarfs spawn continously and move about the mine map on their own.  You guide them and coax them to do your bidding to explore, gain money/increase score.  As more dwarfs spawn the harder it is to control them.There are no complicated elements to distract you from the main aim of the game which is to guide your dwarfs as they mine the map uncovering resources or caves with rewards or dangers.  You can build outposts with guards to fight off monsters, use dynamite to cut-off dangerous traps or turn earth to concetre to block of sections you dont want your miners to explore.  These simple mechanics mean you can get into the game very, very quickly.  However just because it is simple to play does not mean it is easy to master...  The game has a lot of depth with several game modes including a set of campaign challenges which plays like a tutorial that gets harder and encourages you to develop your technique.  These will become vital in the Arcade mode or the Skirmish challenges.  Gameplay remains the same throughout with the difficultly and the achievements being the driver for you to take on harder and harder challenges.Overall I found this fun if the last few challenges a little frustrating but, its great to start up if you just want some quick frantic fun for an hour or so.  It is repetitive with only the randomly drawn maps changing from game to game.  Though for what it costs its value for money.  Just dont expect AAA graphics.

												Damn dwarves, always digging too deep… Uh… Erm-ahem. Hi.If you’re reading this, chances are you’re interested in Dwarfs!?. Maybe you think it could be your kind of game. I have to start by saying that if you’re looking for something remotely like Dwarf Fortress, this is not it. Dwarfs!? is a completely unrelated casual game.With that out of the way, what is Dwarfs!?, really? Well, it’s a game about managing dwarves as they dig further and further from their home. If it doesn’t sound too hard, believe me, this job has a lot more excitement than you think.As the dwarves dig deeper, you’ll want to direct them towards minerals and treasure caves, which boost your score. However, they may also find monsters, water veins, or worse, streams of lava. On that event, you have to try and seal that path before the whole level is flooded and/or your main base is destroyed. This requires an escalating amount of micromanagement, but hey, just try to not die.And… that’s basically it, really. It comes with several modes, each of which has few different rules, but I’ll admit I spent most of my time with the default, arcade mode, which gives you a time limit (5, 15, 30 or 60 minutes) to explore the cave as far as you can and maximize your score. I could have stuck with the F2P version for that, but I don’t regret my purchase. It’s a pretty good casual game that I find myself coming back to every once in a while.…it could have done without the obnoxious voice acting, though.

												This game is okay, its a bit of a laugh.I am a big fan of dwarf fortress and was very excited about picking this up. I had read about it before hand so I didn't feel disapointed about it being completely different, I think one of the developers said "don't think DF, think lemmings" (or maybe it was totalbiscuit, can't remember I'm afraid). Like lemmings, your dwarfs will happily walk to their doom or do something that screws up your entire game. This is where the majority of the challenge comes from and I think the game suffers for that a little. In order to help with that you can change the direction that your dwarf is digging with arrows, make an infintiely deep hole by sacrificing your dwarf (this will allow you to pour water/lava away) and hardening the walls which makes it impossible to dig through. These tools cost you a lot of money so its important to be smart about how you are spending. Yes, those rare crystals would be faster to get to using an arrow but if a dwarf uncovers lava in an open area then you are in real trouble. As the game goes on you will gain more dwarfs which will make earning money much quicker but also opens up problematic areas more quickly too.The nice things about it is that there are a lot of difficulty levels and it requires a lot of concentration. If you enjoy being challenged, you will find that itch scratched in this game. Another nice feature is that you set a time limit before you go in, great if you have a specific amount of time to burn. The graphics and music are nice too.Theres quite a lot of comedy here too. The narrator is voiced by one of the yogscast youtube starts. I'm not too into the yogscast myself but I know it has a lot of fans and some people will just eat that up! The acheivements are fun to get too and its very self aware in its humour.I give it 5/10, to me that's an average game. This doesn't mean I say you should completely ignore it, it's fine and it may turn out that you love it. I think I will pick it up from time to time as it does have an entertaining value to it, but unless its on a steam sale you might want to pass up on this one. I can imagine that people who don't like the "hands off" simulation game like dwarf fortress or dungeon keeper then the on purpose dumb AI could drive them absolutely mad. Personally I think that if you watched a gameplay video of this and you think it looks fun, then you will find it fun. I feel a little bad giving it an average score as there are a lot of fun nice little things here there just isn't too much of it, but what is here is very well polished.I'd love to hear what other players think.

												This is a fun little Arcade/Sim/Strategy game. You start out with a base, which is constantly generating miners which will go out and mine on there on, usually in the general direction of minerals. You can also set down a path that the Dwarf, and any other Dwarf that steps on the path will follow. This is great for getting them to go mine the good stuff. Eventually it gets to the point where there's simply too many miners to micro manage, which is fine and part of the fun. They'll eventually, whether purposely or accidentally  mine into a water reservoir. You have to quickly wall it off and mark the tiles surrounding it as a "don't mine this!" warning, else it'll drown everyone. They'll eventually also mine into lava, which acts almost the same, except it'll burn through your man-made walls, so you have to make a hole in the floor, using dynamite and a Dwarf sacrifice, then mark the walls with a no-mine warning. You have to be quick though, since Dwarfs move slow and the lava needs to be secured before it burns through all your walls.It's fun just mining around, then suddenly one of your Dwarfs off screen will tunnel into lava, then you have to rush to fix it.It's a fun game, though perhaps a bit overpriced at $10. I recommend playing the F2P version, and if you like that, buy the paid version, which offers much more. Though try to get that on sale also.

												TL;DR: Casual lemming manager. Once you get over the tutorial it's a quite okay managing strategy game.Hi mate! Do you like Lemmings? Because that's what Dwarfs basically are, mindless, gold digging lemmings. Get in here and you'll get to be their overlordseer! For good measure, in the tutorial missions you'll also get a grain of rowdy men (or dwarves) talking a bit like pirates or woodchucks, or that's how I imagine people like that would speak. Voice acting sounds horrible. Tutorial's fine otherwise, and the game turns out not too bad either.In Dwarfs!? you control the mindless horde of dwarves on their quest for digging gold and minerals while protecting your base from monsters and natural hazards. Of course, you could just slack off because handing out orders costs precious gold. The dwarves will work independently and bring gold into your coffers. To direct them just makes them go where you want.So why bother? The mine is full of unknown caves and precious minerals. Minerals bring lots of gold and dwarves will only occasionally find them independently. Also, caves contain either treasure or hazard in the form of monsters or sources of rapidly flowing water or lava. All will destroy your base if you don't stop them. So you got to be ready for some overseeing.For monsters you need to send in warriors: you can either build a fort near or send a team in with a catapult. How that works is beyond me, but the warrior dwarves seem unaffected by the flight. For water or lava you got to seal the passage before it overflows your base. Unfortunately (and that's the point) the dwarves are mindless and they will eventually open up more holes for the flows. Your walls and wall sealing techniques will counter these, but usually you need a dwarf to go over there and go all kamikaze with a dynamite to finish the job. Tens or even hundreds of dwarves die each game.Annoyingly, when something (usually bad) happens, you'd of course want to go there immediately. There's usually an icon showing you where it happens and clicking it will get you there instantly. However, there's no button to get back to where you were and if you don't click it fast enough, you'll have to go find it yourself. If it was water or lava, you're probably screwed for that mine.Several game modes will keep you busy: arcade is the classic mode with several difficulty levels that affect the action costs and the frequency of hazardous caves. The hardest setting is actually very difficult indeed requiring loads of overseering to survive. There's also a sort of tower defense mode, a mode with super fast spawning dwarves, a dark mode where you can't see the caves or minerals (very difficult) and a couple of achievement yielding challenges. Plus a meager mini game where you shoot moving boards like in the games of de olde.Curiously this one and the F2P version are considered different games: still, the achievements are transferrable between the two versions so you get 2 perfect games if you can ace this one. F2P version does not contain the most difficult settings and the silly mini game so that's basically what you're paying for. Top Leaderboards are a joke though, as it seems someone has acquired a ludicrous and curiously regular amounts of points in all of them.I recommend it for casual game sessions because I generally enjoyed hoarding the achievements. I'd recommend getting it on sale though, 50 % discount or better. However, if someone asks you to Dwarf in their mine, just don't: the job safety is just not cut for it.

												Lemmings meets tunnels and dwarves.Dwarfs!? is top down 2d strategy game developed by Tripwire Interactive. You play as an overseer whose goal is to manage the dwarve's mining operations and make sure things go smoothly.As an overseer you have to control the safety of your mine through moving units, dealing with environmental hazards and building new structures. Gold is the main currency in the game. It is obtained by simply letting miners detroy blocks on the map. Miners will go off on their own detroying blocks and earning gold and aren't all directly controlled by the player. However, the direction the dwaf is moving in can be manipulated by selecting them and draging  (which creates a path) in a direction to make them move somewhere else. This can't be done sparringly however as it costs gold and the further the direction you send the dwarf, the more it costs. That is why it is best to let the dwarves do their own thing and simply resolve problems when they arise (like lemmings). There are also traps such as water and lava (which floods the mine). When they reach your town hall, the game ends. To deal with this, you have to block the entrance with walls. Lava will break down walls over time, so you have to set explosives to create holes for lava to fall into. Further hazards are enemies such as goblins, spiders, skeletons etc which can be found within the mines. To help deal with these foes you can recruit soldiers. All units gain experience as they complete their tasks, which makes them perform better when they level up. Besides building walls and dynamite, you can also build outposts. Outposts can be used to train your soldiers which increase health and damage. Training takes time and the more time it takes, the more gold it costs.There are plenty of game modes to play. Campaign involves completing challenges which range between getting a certain score, number of units or defeating foes with limited troops. There is also a tower defence mode, where you have to defend your town hall against waves of foes through clever tunnel and tower placement. Arcade mode has you explore a massive map in timed game, trying to get the highest score. Skirmish includes a variety of different modes including a carnival game (where you have to hit the targets) and endless mode (play a 60 minute game). With all theses game modes available, there is plenty of replayability.Audio is decent. The music is alright and gives a somewhat light-hearted medieval feel. Voice acting from the tutorial guy is decent as well.Graphics are dated. Textures don't have alot of detail to them and the models are basic.If you enjoy games where you can sit back and let your workers do most of the work, and solve issues when they occur, as well as having plenty of game modes, this game is for you.

												This is one of those games you play where you enjoy it enough to play for hours, you tell yourself you will definitely play it again in the future, then realize it's for some reason still installed years later and you haven't played it since. Ultimately, think of it as a baby sitting simulator more than a strategy game. You're not managing an army of dwarfs, you're running a daycare center. Some of the kids thinks it's a good idea to dig up a hole where water comes from, forcing you to build blockades or marking various areas as such. You will realize that, the more they expand, the more frustrating it is to manage. Unfortunately, the game is far too laggy for me to play now... for some reason. The frame rate is unplayable. I do not know why suddenly this is a problem, I blame cancer. Unfortunately, google doesn't provide helpful support. I think it has to due with the forced software install when launched. Since google doesn't help with my issue, the forum has no solution to the issue or even the issue being reported, and the fact the forum has been dead for over four years, I'd say I will never be able to play this again. Buy at your own risk.Overall, I recommend this game, but on sale for 75% off. Oh yah, not all achievements work and you're required to play the demo to unlock them. Have fun!
